titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the James Robinson Smith Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Matthew T. MacLean

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday November 29, 2018 at 11:50

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence and subject files primarily documenting the personal life of James Robinson Smith. Several of the subject files document his scholarship, personal beliefs, and work with the Red Cross and food rationing.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: James Robinson Smith Papers (MS 1634). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in two series: I. Correspondence, 1888-1964. II. Subject Files, 1898-1954.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: James Robinson Smith was born in Hartford, Connecticut on December 27, 1876. He graduated from Yale College in 1898 and did graduate work at Yale and Harvard, receiving his M.A. from Yale in 1904. After graduating, he traveled, worked at a variety of jobs, and engaged in literary pursuits. A writer and scholar, he translated Don Quixote and The Earliest Lives of Dante, did scholarly work on Homer's Iliad and the Bible, and published lists of famous men and great quotations. He also wrote poetry. In World War I, Smith worked on and wrote pamphlets about food rationing in European nations, particularly Belgium. After the war he worked in Europe with the American Red Cross. He spent most of the remainder of his life in Nice, France, writing and working at the English-American Library. In 1905 Smith married Martha Butler, who died in 1910. Their daughter, Lucinda, was born in 1909. Smith died in Nice on June 12, 1954.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of correspondence and subject files primarily documenting the personal life of James Robinson Smith. Several of the subject files document his scholarship, personal beliefs, and work with the Red Cross and food rationing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series is arranged in two sections: James Robinson Smith and Lucinda Smith. The James Robinson Smith correspondence comprises non-family and family, incoming and outgoing letters, arranged alphabetically by last name of correspondent. The Lucinda Smith correspondence comprises incoming letters from family members and one folder of letters of condolences she received upon her father's death.

did.unittitle: Condolences [re: death of James Robinson Smith]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The files contain correspondence, publications, and miscellaneous items relating to the professional occupations and personal interests of James Robinson Smith. The series is arranged in alphabetical order by subject.

Belgium [involvement with Commission for Relief in Belgium, 1917-1919]
Famous men [correspondence and his published list of famous men]
